physdesc.extent: 30 manuscript boxes, 14 oversize boxes, 19 oversize folders, 1 microfilm reel

did.abstract: Books, booklets, correspondence, drawings, flyers, forms, leaflets, maps, memorabilia, newspapers and clippings, pamphlets, press releases, sheet music, and other printed matter and ephemera relating to military operations and home front conditions, particularly in Germany and the United States, during World War I.

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: The Hoover Institution Archives only allows access to copies of audiovisual items. To listen to sound recordings or to view videos or films during your visit, please contact the Archives at least two working days before your arrival. We will then advise you of the accessibility of the material you wish to see or hear. Please note that not all audiovisual material is immediately accessible.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: For copyright status, please contact the Hoover Institution Archives.

prefercite.p: [Identification of item], World War I subject collection, [Box no.], Hoover Institution Archives.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Materials acquired by the Hoover Institution Archives.

accruals.head: Accruals
accruals.p: Materials may have been added to the collection since this finding aid was prepared. To determine if this has occurred, find the collection in Stanford University's online catalog at http://searchworks.stanford.edu/. Materials have been added to the collection if the number of boxes listed in the online catalog is larger than the number of boxes listed in this finding aid.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents of Collection
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of a wide assortment of materials relating to World War I, and, to a lesser extent, the period immediately before and after, acquired from and donated by various individuals over time. As a result, in certain instances there are groupings of materials on the same topic, although often there are other materials on the same topic located elsewhere in the collection.

One major topic of the collection is military operations, including recruiting and enlistment; orders and instructions; battle summaries and war news, particularly related to battle lines and fronts (often in the form of maps); and occupation of enemy territory. While there is some material related to the British and French militaries, as well as those of other European countries involved in the war, the bulk of the materials on this topic relate to the German and United States militaries. The American materials are largely about recruiting and enlistment, while the German materials feature war news, military orders, and notices to inhabitants of occupied towns.

Another major topic of the collection is home front conditions, including financing the war, garnering public support for the war, patriotic activities, and rationing. The United War Work Campaign and Liberty bonds in the United States and Kriegsanleihe (war bonds) in Germany are particularly well represented. Also of note are drawings and cartoons, which often depict caricatures of the nations involved in the war, as well as sheet music of patriotic songs, largely from the United States and France. Additionally, there are ration cards from Germany, Great Britain, France, Russia, and Poland and informational materials from the United States about the rationing of food and goods.
The collection also covers the German Revolution of 1918 and the work of welfare/relief organizations such as the Red Cross, Y.M.C.A., American Committee for Relief in the Near East, and others.

Types of materials found on these topics include: books, booklets, correspondence, flyers, forms, leaflets, memorabilia, pamphlets, press releases, and other printed matter and ephemera. Also included in the collection are contemporaneous newspapers and clippings, again predominantly from Germany and the United States, relating news of the war.

did.unittitle: Newspaper clippings, sinking of the Lusitania and service letters,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Three clippings. One, undated, is titled "Berlin Ordered Sinking of Lusitania; Proof of Germany's Crime in Code Cypher." The second, dated April 30, 1961, is titled "American Heritage--Fate Placed Lusitania, U20 in Same Part of Atlantic--And Sent US to War." The third, dated April 20, 1918, consists of service letters written by Paul Galloway, of the 116th field hospital with the American expeditionary forces, to his parents and a brother.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reprint of a satirical drawing from Life, distributed by The American Rights Committee, imagining what a map of North America would look like if the United States lost the war (e.g., New Prussia, Japonica, Turconia).

did.unittitle: Essays for Americans by Florizel von Reuter,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Three essays intended for American audiences written by Florizel von Reuter, an American living in Germany and a correspondent on the staff of the Neutral Committee for Neutral Reports, Berlin. The essays, which are pro-Germany, are titled, "The Attitude of the United States. Is America Neutral?," "Was Belgium's Attitude Towards Germany Justified?," and "More Triple Entente Fables About German Atrocities."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Pro-German leaflet asserting Germany's desire for peace.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Pro-German leaflet asserting that prior to the outbreak of the war "Belgium was conniving with the Entente Powers."

did.unittitle: Leaflet, "Deceiving the Whole World. American Newspaper Men Arrested in London for Telling the Truth about Germany. -- A Personal Letter,"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Pro-German declaration by the Committee of The American Truth Society in Munich concluding that England is directly responsible for the war.

did.unittitle: Zettel, Bilder und Zeitschriftenfolgen, Subject File,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: These items were gathered together by a donor. According to a type-written note at the front, they are various printed materials that were dropped by Allied planes over German lines, mostly demanding an end to the war. They were not in a discernible order, so they have been arranged by document type, with a few exceptions (one, where there were many instances of a single publication and two, when the items were in languages other than German). Where possible, the items were removed from the construction paper they were on. Some of the items are annotated/described by the compiler of the album. In German, unless otherwise noted.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: These items all have "By Balloon/Durch Luftballon" printed on them, and they are numbered as well, suggesting that they are part of a series of a publication.

did.unittitle: Tables, "Losses in Men and Ships Suffered by Italy During the War,"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Five tables: 1) Losses suffered by the Italian army and navy from 23 May 1915 to 11 November 1918; 2) Casualties in officers and men; 3) Summary of the disabled from war causes; 4) Losses in the Royal Navy; 5) Italian merchant ships sunk by submarines and mines.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Cards of "memorable utterances of President Wilson" illustrated by Gustave Jacobs for the students of France (in French). Also included is a letter, stamped 21 February 1919, from the Minister of Public Education in France informing the educational authorities in the United States about the creation of the cards and enclosing a set.

did.unittitle: British, French, and American materials re monetary support of the war,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes a British leaflet about saving money; French leaflets dropped from airplanes about the 3rd Defense Loan; an American Victory Bonds pin, and Worcester War Chest tags. In English and French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Two leaflets: one, titled "To our colleagues in Russia," which discusses the inspiration the authors have drawn from Russian literature and Russia as a worthy ally in the war; the other, titled "The War: Declaration by British Authors," expressing their opinion that Great Britain was right to enter the war and their support for the Allies' cause.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Correspondence (1918-1919), publications ("Le Problème des Nationalités," by Th. Ruyssen, 1916 and "The Secret History of a Great Betrayal, Sixth Edition," by E.D. Morel, 1925), and a photocopy of Matthias' obituary, 1983.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: One Franc; stickers to fasten posters that say "Armenia: The most tragic story in human history;" wallet-sized fold-out "Flags of the Allies;" Camps Library bookmarks about donating books or magazines; Smileage Books of coupons for military entertainment venues; Worcester, MA employee identification cards; blank participation cards related to "l'Oeuvre;" notice from the 84th U.S. Infantry "Railsplitter" Division to German soldiers urging them to surrender; roster of German officers with rank and date of death (if applicable).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The majority of the items are from the publisher/printer Coquemer and include, among other things, a notice about a reproduction of the painting "L'Aube de la Revanche;" "Elle Tiendra" leaflet; informational leaflets; a book jacket, and a notice about the publication of a patriotic calendar for 1918.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes two sets of War Designs postcards illustrated by Frank Brangwyn, as well as a set of U.S. Marines postcards. Most of the items are in French.

did.unittitle: Booklet, "Report of General John J. Pershing, U.S.A.,"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Text of a cable from Pershing, Commander-in-Chief of the American Expeditionary Forces, to the Secretary of War, 20 November 1918. The cover notes that it was corrected 16 January 1919. The maps meant to accompany the report can be found in the Map case, Folder 1, Items 4 and 5.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The 1917 pocket-sized calendar, in Italian, is published by the Banca Italiana di Sconto. The 1919 wallet-sized calendars, in French, feature photographs or drawings and quotations relating to the war.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes a notice from Marshall Foch about the ceasing of hostilities on 11 November 1918; a letter dated 30 November 1918 from William Joseph Shipsey about his experience fighting in the war; correspondence from August 1917 about a false French publisher who went by the name Delandre; and a postcard dated 1 March 1919. In English and French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Nine cartoons by Max Beerbohm, reproduced in the Manchester Guardian Weekly, depicting the relationship between England, France, and Germany from the early years of the nineteenth century through January 1923.

did.unittitle: Clippings, George F. Rand and the Bayonet Trench Monument,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The first set of clippings, from roughly September 1919 to April 1920 (plus one post card from August 1922), concerns George F. Rand, and mainly consists of obituaries published after his untimely death in a plane crash. The second set of clippings, from roughly May 1920 to January 1921, concerns the building and dedication of the Bayonet Trench Monument, which Rand funded. There is also an article from January 1926 about the tragedy of the Bayonet Trench, as well as a letter from January 1950 to a relative of Rand's about the Monument at Verdun. It appears that some of the clippings, which were glued onto pages, are missing. Others were loose and did not appear to match any of the existing pages.

Performances in Aubigny, Breisach, Brügge, Brussels, Bucharest, Buzancy, Cambrai, Charleroi, Corbon, Dusseldorf, Elbing, Fouquières, Ghent, Ghistel, Givet, Hirson, Jelowka, Juniville, Keyem, Königsberg, Krusevica, Lecluse, Levico, Lille, Lislet, Longwy, Lötzen, Lüttich, Marville, Maubeuge, Mouzon, Namur, Nanteuil, Ostend, Poniewicz, Posen, Roeselare, St. Amand.

Truppe performances - Abt. 2; Polish material - Abt. 3. Nos. 1-11; Roumania - Abt. 3. Nos. 12-21; Smyrna and Turkey - Abt. 3. Nos. 22-45; three German posters at end of file.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes two letters, dated 25 April 1917, to a postmaster, informing him of his duties to assist as a recruiting officer and to report suspicious characters or treasonous acts. With these letters is a form to fill out, Obligation as Recruiting Agent, as well as a copy of the Order of the Postmaster General of 9 April 1917 (which references the Acts of June 3 and August 2, 1916 and the use of the services of postmasters). There is also a follow-up letter requesting that the Obligation, which had not yet been returned, be signed promptly and sent back. In addition, there is an instruction sheet regarding mail for the U.S. Army in Europe (28 July 1917) and a message regarding the acceptance of orders for Army foodstuffs (20 September 1919).

All three bills were introduced by Mr. John E. Raker, a representative from California.

did.unittitle: Poster, "Seine kaiserliche und königlich Apostolische Majestät…,"
Maps, Enemy Order of Battle, First Army, American Expeditionary Forces, No. 124,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: These maps depict the Western Front from 1 September 1918 to 11 November 1918.

did.unittitle: Maps, Graphic Summary of Enemy Activity, First Army, American Expeditionary Forces, No. 124,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: These maps depict the Western Front from 1 October 1918 to 11 November 1918.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Handwritten notes on back: "British Military maps, Somme complete, 1916." "British War Office Official Map. Amiens - Peronne area. Scene of British 5th Army retreat, March and April 1918. This map is heavily taped. However, given that it is an officially produced map without annotations, the decision was made to not take extensive preservation action.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Handwritten notes on back: "British Military maps, 1916, Doullens-Arras Bapaume areas." "Official Map - Doullens-Bapaume area. Scene of trench digging and wiring activity April 1918 by entire regiment between Terra Mesnil and Le Val de Maison." This map is heavily taped. However, given that it is an officially produced map without annotations, the decision was made to not take extensive preservation action.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Handwritten notes on back: "World War One map, British Front, vicinity St. Quentin." "British War Office Official Map. Roisel-Tincourt, St. Quentin areas." This map is heavily taped. However, given that it is an officially produced map without annotations, the decision was made to not take extensive preservation action.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Handwritten notes on back: "British Military maps, 1916. Cambrai attack 11/20/1917, German counterattack 11/30/1917." "British War Office Official Map. Fins-Gouzeaucourt, Cambrai area. Cambrai Offensive 11/20/17, Cambrai Defensive 11/30/17, Somme Defensive 3/21/18." This map is heavily taped. However, given that it is an officially produced map without annotations, the decision was made to not take extensive preservation action.

did.unittitle: Backgammon board made by a Bulgarian soldier during World War I,
Two samples of materials of German sand bags,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A note with the samples reads: "These materials are of woven paper fiber in place of yute, of which supply was exhausted. These materials were picked up in 1918 just across the German line in the Meuse Argonne area."
